repository.corpname: Western Connecticut State University Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: Horace Purdy served in the 1st Connecticut Regiment during the Civil War. This is a collection of his journals from 1860 to 1905.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Likely the microfilm was obtained by Truman Warner. The original diary was microfilmed in 1965 for the Scott Fanton Museum in Danbury, CT.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research without restrictions. A digitized copy is currently being processed and is the preferred means of access.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:Identification of item, date (if known); The Journals of Horace Purdy; MS 044; box number; folder number; Western Connecticut State University

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Originals are held by the Scott Fanton Museum (Danbury Historical Society)

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The journals begin as Horace Purdy and wife Gussie begin their married life together in Danbury where they are active with their church and where they own a house with tenants. In 1860, Purdy was in the Wooster Light Guards militia company and appeared to have been the secretary. Gussie and Horace socialize frequently with Gussie's parents, Mrs. (referred to as Mother Griswold) and Father Griswold who was a prominent Methodist minister in the area. Purdy works in a hat shop and is busiest in the Winter and frequently suffers from headaches. He also works in his vegetable garden in the spring growing strawberries, lima beans, etc. His political leanings appear to have been Republican but there was much political activity among both parties in the run up to the local elections of 1860. Purdy reports on the activities of the "Wide Awakes" and it appears likely that he belonged to the group but he did not explicitly state that he was a member.

At the outbreak of the Civil War, Purdy joined the 1st Connecticut which was a 3 month enlistment regiment and was organized at Hartford in 1861. It served in the defenses of Washington, D.C. until it was used in an advance on Vienna and Falls Church, VA from June until July, 1861. It saw action in the Battle of Bull Run on July 21 and was mustered out of service on July 31, 1861.

After his term of service, Purdy returns to Danbury where he eventually transitions from being a hat finisher to selling insurance. Purdy reports on the minutia of his day, the weather and occasionally reports on national events with few editorial embellishments.

list.item: Civil War Soldiers and Sailors System. "1st Connecticut Infantry" [http://www.itd.nps.gov/cwss/regiments.cfm]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains 6 volumes of Journals on one microfilm reel. Volumes 1 - 2 contain materials regarding Purdy's experiences in the Civil War; volumes 3 - 5 contain materials regarding his life from 1866 - 1870 and Volume 6 contains materials regarding his life from 1904 - Feb 9, 1905.
